What is described as the most ambitious play the Playshop has ever
undertaken will be presented by the
local dramatic organization for five
evening performances beginning the
week of February 20, when Hedda
Gabbler, by Hendrik Ibsen, will be
produced at the Homewood Theatre, with Miss Frances Jordan in the
leading role.
Miss Jordan started her dramatic
career with the Playshop five years
ago when she acted in a play that
was produced on the steps of Gilman Hall. Since then she has had
the lead in Faith Healer, by William Moody, and Martin Fleming,
by James Herne, in addition to
many minor roles in other Playshop
productions.
Members Of Cast

The other members of the cast
include Peter Weisengoff, who has
played with the Barnstormers and
Vagabonds; Isabelle Idov, connected with the Auditorium Players;
Tom Pinkerton, who had the lead
in Moliere's The Miser, produced
last year; Patty Singewald, Helen
Ascherfeld, and David Lovett.
The production is under the direction of Dr. N. Bryllion Fagin.
The plot of this play centers
about Hedda Gabler, an attractive
but impoverished society woman.
Unable to marry within her own
set, Hedda weds a poor, dull scholar
and is unhappy afterward. Dr. Fagin has described the drama as
"representing a study of the destructive female who plays with men
and then destroys them because she
has not the courage to have a good
time with them and is too bored to
leave them alone."

In order to discuss proposals
which constitute a program to build
up the class treasuries for the senior years, a joint meeting of the
freshman and sophomore classes will
be held immediately after the assembly Thursday.
Originally scheduled for last
Thursday, the meeting was postponed due to the lack of a quorum.
Plans for a combined dance and a
condensed banquet season will be
subjected to the approval of the
members of the classes.
By reinstating the old plan of a
combined dance, it is hoped that this
will be the first step in the fulfillment of the plan to reduce senior
dues.

DRS. HOLT, HARPER
RELEASE VOLUMES
Press Announces Publication
Of Books By Hopkins
Instructors
Treaties Defeated By The Senate, by Dr. W. Stull Holt, Associate Professor in History, has recently been released by the Johns
Hopkins Press. Dr. Holt has long
been a student of treaties and foreign relations. His new book is a
study of the struggle between President and Senate over the conduct
of foreign relations.
In treating the question, Dr. Holt
has viewed the subject from different aspects and shows the affect each
has had upon it. Two-thirds of the
book is devoted to the period since
the Civil War.
Versailles Treaty Treated

A brief chapter, enriched by material from the manuscript papers
of Bryan, explains the ratification
of the treaty of peace in 1899, which
presents some exceptional features.
In the long concluding chapter of
the Versailles treaty, emphasis is
placed on the contest within the Republican party upon which depended
the fate of the treaty and of the
world.
The Press also announced the
publishing of Cardinal Newman and
William Froude, R.F.S., by Dr.
Gordon Huntington Harper, of the
English department.
In this volume Dr. Harper has
gathered the correspondence between these two men dating over a
period of fifty years, most of which
has never before been printed. The
subject matter concerns the grounds
for religious belief, Newman vainly seeking to convince Froude of
the greater value of Roman Catholicism in comparison with the scientific spirit of the time.
The author has supplied his own
introduction and a series of running comments throughout the book.

What is described as the most ambitious play the Playshop has ever
undertaken will be presented by the
local dramatic organization for five
evening performances beginning the
week of February 20, when Hedda
Gabbler, by Hendrik Ibsen, will be
produced at the Homewood Theatre, with Miss Frances Jordan in the
leading role.
Miss Jordan started her dramatic
career with the Playshop five years
ago when she acted in a play that
was produced on the steps of Gilman Hall. Since then she has had
the lead in Faith Healer, by William Moody, and Martin Fleming,
by James Herne, in addition to
many minor roles in other Playshop
productions.
Members Of Cast

The other members of the cast
include Peter Weisengoff, who has
played with the Barnstormers and
Vagabonds; Isabelle Idov, connected with the Auditorium Players;
Tom Pinkerton, who had the lead
in Moliere's The Miser, produced
last year; Patty Singewald, Helen
Ascherfeld, and David Lovett.
The production is under the direction of Dr. N. Bryllion Fagin.
The plot of this play centers
about Hedda Gabler, an attractive
but impoverished society woman.
Unable to marry within her own
set, Hedda weds a poor, dull scholar
and is unhappy afterward. Dr. Fagin has described the drama as
"representing a study of the destructive female who plays with men
and then destroys them because she
has not the courage to have a good
time with them and is too bored to
leave them alone."

In order to discuss proposals
which constitute a program to build
up the class treasuries for the senior years, a joint meeting of the
freshman and sophomore classes will
be held immediately after the assembly Thursday.
Originally scheduled for last
Thursday, the meeting was postponed due to the lack of a quorum.
Plans for a combined dance and a
condensed banquet season will be
subjected to the approval of the
members of the classes.
By reinstating the old plan of a
combined dance, it is hoped that this
will be the first step in the fulfillment of the plan to reduce senior
dues.

RELEASE VOLUMES
Press Announces Publication
Of Books By Hopkins
Instructors
Treaties Defeated By The Senate, by Dr. W. Stull Holt, Associate Professor in History, has recently been released by the Johns
Hopkins Press. Dr. Holt has long
been a student of treaties and foreign relations. His new book is a
study of the struggle between President and Senate over the conduct
of foreign relations.
In treating the question, Dr. Holt
has viewed the subject from different aspects and shows the affect each
has had upon it. Two-thirds of the
book is devoted to the period since
the Civil War.
Versailles Treaty Treated

A brief chapter, enriched by material from the manuscript papers
of Bryan, explains the ratification
of the treaty of peace in 1899, which
presents some exceptional features.

The Press also announced the
publishing of Cardinal Newman and
William Froude, R.F.S., by Dr.
Gordon Huntington Harper, of the
English department.
In this volume Dr. Harper has
gathered the correspondence between these two men dating over a
period of fifty years, most of which
has never before been printed. The
subject matter concerns the grounds
for religious belief, Newman vainly seeking to convince Froude of
the greater value of Roman Catholicism in comparison with the scientific spirit of the time.
The author has supplied his own
introduction and a series of running comments throughout the book.
